fact_list.fact_text: Traffic conditions vary depending on time, place and situation.
Traffic may be congested or relatively light.
The speed of other vehicles also varies.
Try to drive with the traffic in order not to disrupt its flow.
Adjust your speed to the traffic and road situation.
Situations change as you travel from urban built-up areas to sub-urban and then to rural areas.
In urban areas, traffic is slow and heavy.
Traffic is faster and lighter in suburban areas.
In rural areas, traffic is generally light.
Whatever the traffic conditions, the driver has the responsibility to be careful and alert at all times.
Most countries in Europe adopt a left-hand drive system.
Youâ€™ll find the steering wheel on the other side of the car in countries with a left-hand drive system.
Being prepared will allow you to drive more confidently.
Stop before and close to the stop-line.
Leave a safety gap of 2 meters between your vehicle and the vehicle in front.
Apply the handbrake after stopping.
Be alert to the traffic around you while waiting for the lights to change.
Position your vehicle in the center of the lane.
Move only when the lights turn green.
Look to the right and left for approaching vehicles before moving.
Look out for pedestrians crossing the road in front of you.
Wait 2 seconds after the vehicle in front has moved off before proceeding.
Proceed only in the direction indicated on the lane.
Give way to vehicles beating the lights.
